stimulusHtml:
Show all your work. Indicate clearly the methods you use, because you will be scored on the correctness of your methods as well as on the accuracy and completeness of your results and explanations.

 

Consider a study designed to investigate the following claim.

A medicated eye drop is effective in relieving itchy eyes.

Two designs are proposed for the study.

  • Plan A: Obtain 240 volunteers from the population of people with itchy eyes. Randomly assign 160 of the volunteers to use the medicated eye drop each day. Assign the remaining 80 volunteers to use a placebo each day. Observe the number of people who experience relief in each group after one week.
  • Plan B: Randomly select 240 people from the population of people with itchy eyes to use the medicated eye drop each day and observe the number of people who experience relief after one week.

(a) Give an example of what people assigned to use a placebo in Plan A might be asked to use instead of the medicated eye drop. Explain the benefit of the placebo in the context of the study.

(b) For which plan can the results of the study be generalized to all people who have itchy eyes? Explain, in the context of the study, the characteristic of the plan that allows for this generalization.

A researcher conducted the study described in Plan A and estimated the difference in the proportions of people similar to those in the study who would experience relief for the two treatments. Assume all conditions for inference were met. The resulting 99 percent confidence interval (Medicated Eye Drop minus Placebo) is 0.13Â±0.15.

(c) Does the 99 percent confidence interval provide evidence to support the claim? Justify your answer.
(d) Suppose that the researcher instead decided to compute a 95 percent confidence interval for the same sample data. Would this change impact your answer in part (c)? Explain your reasoning.

The researcher plans to randomly select people from the study, one at a time and without replacement, to be interviewed. The interviews will continue until 20 people who had received the medicated eye drop are interviewed. Let the random variable A represent the total number of people interviewed.

(e) Explain, in the context of the study, why the random variable A does not follow a binomial distribution.
